qas.question: What enhances the vertical look of the exterior of Gothic construction?
What is one design element of Gothic construction that is often terminated by small pinnacles?
What is another design element of Gothic construction that is often terminated by small pinnacles?
Which cathedral demonstrates a drastic example of termination with small pinnacles?
What other part of Gothic buildings are often found terminated with small pinnacles?
What hinders the vertical look of the exterior of Gothic construction?
What is one design element of Gothic construction that is always terminated by small pinnacles?
Which cathedral demonstrates an impossible structure of small pinnacles?
What part of Gothic buildings are often found terminated with enormous pinnacles?

context: On the exterior, the verticality is emphasised in a major way by <a0_0><b5_0>the towers and spires<b5_0/><a0_0/> and in a lesser way by strongly projecting vertical <b8_0>buttresses<b8_0/>, by narrow half-columns called attached shafts which often pass through several storeys of the building, by long narrow windows, vertical mouldings around doors and figurative sculpture which emphasises the vertical and is often attenuated. <a1_0>The roofline<a1_0/>, <a2_0><b6_0>gable ends<b6_0/><a2_0/>, <a4_0>buttresses<a4_0/> and other parts of the building are often terminated by small pinnacles, <a3_0><b7_0>Milan Cathedral<b7_0/><a3_0/> being an extreme example in the use of this form of decoration.
